11:13 am
BE11:13am

Given everyone from Jamie Dimon down has said repeatedly over the past few years that it's going to be a disaster, and also given that there are small details like passporting and data laws underpinning a few hundred thousand "banker" jobs.

luzh I thought "People's Vote" was a silly name but it actually caught on for a while.
BE11:14am

The BoML fund manager survey -- probably the best gauge of "banker" sentiment we have -- has been shouting "Brexit = bad" for about four years now.

BE11:15am

Nevertheless, I guess we shouldn't be too critical of anything that gives Magic Grandpa a populist line to say something, rather than nothing.

Entertainment One Ltd (ETO:LSE): Last: 591.50, up 6.5 (+1.11%), High: 593.00, Low: 580.50, Volume: 2.09m
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 841.20, up 0.2 (+0.02%), High: 842.00, Low: 840.40, Volume: 1.34m

Though Disney/Netflix/Amazon would likely be most attracted to the film business. Peppa Pig is a useful media property but not necessarily a premium subscription one, not least because the Under 5s don't really care whethey they're watching in 4K HD or on pirate Youtube.

madrugada Welcome back BE. I hope you feel rejuvenated after your holiday.
nichoman since donald offered to buy greenland, why doesn't the US just offer to buy the whole of the FTSE 250 for say a 30% premium?

2s10s was POTUS making a global heating play re Greenland?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

air price for existing brands. We view it a sensible price for the existing brands and assets, although little appears to be included for newer brands (Ricky Zoom, launching in September) and any synergy's ($130m targeted) would also be kept for the Hasbro shareholders. The offer price is in line with our target price, which is based upon a DCF SOTP model of the Family and FTD divisions separately, reflecting the different growth and risk profiles and capital requirements of the various businesses.

Counter bid? Entertainment One's diverse mix of entertainment assets across Family, TV, Music and Film, could in theory hold appeal for a variety of businesses. However, this diversity also brings complexity, and these businesses have had the opportunity to get involved at a much lower valuation than that offered. The global platforms and vertically integrated entertainment groups (Netflix, Disney etc.), may be better served seeing what Hasbro decides to do with the non-family divisions, rather than challenge a Hasbro offer at this stage in the day. Other would-be-contenders, such as ITV, we believe would find it difficult to justify a price above the current offer given limited synergies (vs Hasbro's targeted $130m).

nichoman do these media giants need to own Peppa pig and everything else that goes with it ? can't they just licence it ?
Dr B Welcome back BE! Higher bid spec coming out of JE?
undefined
BE11:28am

(@nichoman: indeed. This idea that Netflix will be the buyer of default for content ignores the fact that a very high proportion of Netflix shows are branded "exclusive" and are supplied by external production companies, with the exclusivity often simply a regional thing.)

nightingale20201 didn't Hasbro have to raise debt $1bn to fund for this....and take 3/4 years to get the increased debt level back to their long term guidance ....so earnings accretive or not? doesnt sound good

And in terms of the other fantasy counterbid story .....

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 753.80, down 18.4 (-2.38%), High: 768.40, Low: 741.00, Volume: 2.93m
BE11:30am

Shares down on an Exane downgrade.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Sector thing. Making the point that Just Eat isn't a bad business, it's just in a bad market.

BE11:31am

And why should we think Takeaway.com's allegedly better management will make a better fist of that market?

BE11:31am

The same argument goes for counterbid theories .....

Sails Welcome back BE
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Uber and Deliveroo have messed with the winner-take-all economics of chow mien delivery in the UK so unless they want to buy JE -- and there's no sign that they do -- you're talking about a new entrant wanting to compete with a wall of PE money.

BE11:33am

Here's Exane.

BE11:33am

If Takeaway.com’s shares are over-valued, so are Just Eats; we now rate both
Underperform
The consensus view of the food delivery space is that bigger is better. Whilst we certainly wouldn’t
want to be a sub-scale operator in the industry, we’re increasingly of the view that size isn’t
everything. In particular, cross-border border mergers like Takeaway.com’s proposed purchase of
Just Eat seem unlikely to us to step-change either business’ prospects. With Just Eat’s shares
trading close to the implied offer price but linked to a currency (Takeaway shares) we think has
downside risks (we’re Underperform Takeaway), we move our rating on Just Eat to Underperform.
It’s not clear to us how Takeaway.com can make Just Eat a much better business
With low cost synergies (EUR20m by year 4, just 2% of our combined EBITDA estimate) the
upside from Takeaway.com’s proposed acquisition of Just Eat needs to be better management but
we’re not sure what can be done better. We think the primary challenge of Just Eat is competition
and though Takeaway.com sees little in its core markets, those markets haven’t seen the kind of
investment the UK has. Further, the prospect of buying out competition in the UK as Takeaway did
in Germany seems low to us too. Meanwhile we’re not expecting a higher bid for Just Eat.

Sails Just Eat is the new Debenhams, as in it's the share UK investors obsess about
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Add in JE management approval, PE focus on early stage, Napsers focus on emerging markets and the CMA throwing sand into the wheels of sector consolidation and you're probably not expecting any kind of counter.

BE11:51am

Here's Goldman's morning thing, which has probably been rendered obsolete already by whatever he tweeted this morning from the toilet of the Biarritz branch of Hooters.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

What matters today
Announcements over the weekend represent another significant escalation in the US-China trade conflict. In response to China’s proposed retaliatory tariffs of 5-10% on Chinese imports from the US totaling c.$66bn on Friday (Aug 23), President Trump announced that the US would impose additional tariffs on US imports from China. He also threatened to invoke the US International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to curtail US firms’ transactions with Chinese entities. For now, our economists make the assumption that the proposed tariff increases are implemented in Sept and Oct; however, they believe that the Dec 15 round will be implemented at 10% rather than the newly proposed 15% and that the IEEPA is not formally invoked.

BE11:52am

Following the additional trade war escalation as well as Chair Powell’s Jackson Hold address, last week our macro team increased subjective odds to 80% of a 25bp cut at the September meeting, to 20% chance of a 50bp cut, and to less than 5% chance of no cut (vs. 75%/15%/10% previously). For the October meeting they see a 60% chance of a 25bp cut, a 15% chance of a 50bp cut, and a 25% chance of no cut.
On China, they see significant downside risk to growth on the back of slower recent growth, rapidly escalating external pressure and restrained domestic policy stimulus. They expect policymakers to take at least some initial steps to address this across monetary policy (modest cuts to the MLF and OMO rates), credit policy (RRR cuts and window guidance), and fiscal policy (an increase in the special bond issuance quota for 2019).

target levels, with Vale recording its best shipment level YTD.
 Steel mill production curtailments in Tangshan over September could drive
upward pressure on steel margins and thus support iron ore prices.
 Current iron ore prices continue to drive earnings momentum, with EPS and
valuation upside at spot into the medium term despite the price fall

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

As for equity strat ........ here's UBS.

BE12:04pm

Broad-based global slowdown: a full 70% of the world's country PMIs now
below 50. The breadth in country PMIs around the world has deteriorated amidst the
downtrend in the Global PMI. A full 76% of countries had a PMI reading above 50 at
the beginning of 2019 compared to just 30% today.
Heightened volatility: weaker prospects have left U.S. equities vulnerable to
negative news. The S&P 500's ability to deal with disappointing news was far better
in 2016 and 2017 when PMIs were trending upwardly. The magnitude of equity
corrections has increased significantly since the peak in PMIs in early 2018.

BE12:04pm

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Broadening earnings deterioration: # of S&P 500 companies with negative
earnings growing. There are now 137 companies in the S&P 500 with negative
earnings growth compared to 68 at the beginning of 2019. Leading Economic
Indicators argue that earnings breadth will deteriorate further in the coming quarters.
Surprising leadership: U.S. companies with high-China sales outperforming
thus far in 2019. S&P 500 companies that derive a higher share of revenues from
China than their peers are outperforming this year despite the global slowdown in PMIs
and lingering trade issues.

BE12:05pm

Couple more charts.
